I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  Central and South Asia faces a new era as peace returned to Afghanistan after years of 
conflict. Massive international relief and rehabilitation assistance is taking place in Afghanistan. 
These  developments  have  opened  up  new  opportunities  for  the  region  to  achieve  sustained 
economic  growth  and  poverty  reduction.  Key  to  achieving  these  goals  is  developing  efficient 
transport corridors that connect landlocked Central Asia republics to seaports in the Arabian Sea 
and the Persian Gulf via Afghanistan.  
 
2.  Afghanistan, Pakistan, Tajikistan, Uzbekistan, and Iran as an observer1 participated in the 
First Ministerial Conference on Transport and Trade in Central and South Asia hosted by the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) and held in Manila on 31 July–1 August 2003. Those countries agreed to 
establish the Central and South Asia Transport and Trade Forum (CSATTF) as the instrument to 
facilitate  transport  connectivity  and  trade  in  the  subregion.  ADB  immediately  responded  by 
providing regional technical assistance (TA) for Subregional Economic Cooperation in South and 
Central Asia (SECSCA) for $600,000, approved in December 2003, which focused mainly on 
CSATTF.  The  Secretariat  was  established  in  South  Asia  Department  (SARD)  and  CSATTF 
member  countries  are  Afghanistan,  Pakistan,  Tajikistan,  Turkmenistan,  Uzbekistan,  and  Iran.2 
Phase I will be completed in December 2005. The concept paper for SECSCA Phase II was 
approved by the ADB Management on 31 October 2005.3 The design and monitoring framework is 
in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  The major challenges to transport and trade facilitation in the subregion identified at the 
beginning of CSATTF were (i) poor or inadequate infrastructure facilities, (ii) limited coordination of 
infrastructure  investments,  (iii)  restrictive  trade  policies,  (iv)  limited  regulatory  frameworks,  (v) 
different  customs  laws  and  procedures,  (vi)  underdeveloped  transport  logistics  services,  (vii) 
security concerns regarding drugs and human trafficking, and (viii) capacity constraints in both 
public and private sectors.  
 
4.  During  the  last  2  years,  CSATTF  has  addressed  these  challenges  through  a  corridor 
development plan, focusing on two main transport corridors4 and covering the five major areas: (i) 
infrastructure improvement (road and border infrastructure); (ii) customs cooperation; (iii) transit 
arrangements; (iv) anti-trafficking activities; and (v) consultations, knowledge sharing, and capacity 
development. In conjunction with CSATTF, ADB has actively provided financial assistance totaling 
$726.7 million to Afghanistan and Pakistan for improving road infrastructure and border facilities, 
and  to  Tajikistan  for  modernizing  customs  procedures;  and  supporting  trade  and  transport 
facilitation through technical assistance totaling $1.15 million. ADB has actively pursued close 
operational  coordination  with  its  development  partners  that  support  the  above-mentioned  five

Afghanistan–Iran  section  (about  2,800  km),  (ii)  Uzbekistan–Afghanistan–Iran  section  (about  3,200  km),  and

areas.5 CSATTF has also maintained close operational coordination with the regional programs 
conducted  by  ADB’s  East  and  Central  Asia  Department  (ECRD)  and  Economic  Cooperation 
Organization (ECO). This coordination has aimed at avoiding overlapping initiatives, achieving 
synergistic benefits wherever possible, and supporting together trade and transport facilitation.  
 
5.  Road Infrastructure. Road links along the two CSATTF corridors have been improved 
steadily during the last 2 years. Before CSATTF, about 40% of the total length of each transport 
corridor was considered in good condition with adequate maintenance, while the remaining 60% 
was identified as in need of rehabilitation or upgrading. Presently, about 40% of the total length of 
each corridor (about 1,100 kilometers [km]) has been improved or is being improved with external 
assistance,  leaving  about  20%  for  rehabilitation  and  upgrading.  ADB  has  contributed  to  the 
improvement of a total of about 940 km along the North–South Corridor (about 34% of the total 
length) and about 740 km (about 26%) along the East–West Corridor.6 
 
6.  Traffic has built up significantly along the CSATTF corridors in Afghanistan, while there has 
been a steady buildup in other CSATTF countries.7 Despite the current road transport constraints, 
regional and transit trade moving along both corridors has been significant, especially through 
Torkham/Landi Kotal, Spin Boldak/Chamman, and Islam Qala/Dogharun border crossings. An ADB-
financed master plan study for Afghanistan8 estimates that the traffic level along the CSATTF 
corridors would more than double by 2015. Future traffic developments will require further road 
improvement or widening of the regional highways in Afghanistan and along the two transport 
corridors in its neighboring countries.9 To systematically identify necessary transport infrastructure 
and  service  improvement  for  effective  consultations  with  CSATTF  members  and  development 
partners, a diagnostic assessment of all available transport modes along the transport corridors and 
a strategy and action plan are considered necessary. 
 
7.  Border Infrastructure. Transport and trade along the CSATTF corridors are presently 
constrained at the transport nodes where transshipment often takes place and where infrastructure 
facilities, mostly border facilities, need further development or improvement. Under CSATTF, the 
eight major border crossings have been identified along the two corridors.10

8.  ADB is currently assisting Pakistan in developing and upgrading border facilities adjacent to 
Afghanistan at Chamman, Ghlam Khan, and Torkham.11 At the Second Ministerial Conference 
(March 2005), CSATTF countries agreed to adopt a coordinated development program for border 
crossing facilities and operations. The physical infrastructure and procedural aspects of all CSATTF 
border points and the major inland clearing depots (ICDs) in Afghanistan have been reviewed.12 
The findings will serve as a basis in preparing a coordinated CSATTF border facility development 
strategy and action program, reflecting activities by development partners. 
 
9.  Customs  Procedures.  The  border  and  clearance  procedures  in  Afghanistan  and  its 
neighboring countries do not yet conform to international best practice. Although developments are 
leading in that direction, there is still a degree of inconsistency in relation to the requirements at 
different  border  crossings  and  ICDs.  CSATTF  has  identified  the  four  major  areas  to  address 
customs-related  issues:  (i)  simplification  and  harmonization  of  customs  procedures  and 
documentation, (ii) information and communications technology-based data sharing for customs 
operations, (iii) application of modern customs techniques, and (iv) capacity building of local and 
national customs administration officials. The framework of the customs cooperation plan was 
endorsed  at  the  Second  Ministerial  Conference,  and  the development  of  a  CSATTF  customs 
strategy and action plan reflecting activities by development partners13 is expected. 
 
10.  Transit Systems. In addition to physical improvement of the transport corridors, improving 
the transit systems is crucial to the goals of CSATTF. CSATTF has adopted two approaches: (i) 
accession to the relevant international conventions, and (ii) development of efficient corridor transit 
systems.  Of  nine  conventions  identified,14  five  CSATTF  member  countries  have  completed 
accession to three: (i) Convention on Road Traffic, (ii) Convention on Road Signs and Signals, and 
(iii)  Customs  Convention  on  International  Transport  of  Goods  under  Cover  of  the  Transports 
Internationaux  Routiers  (TIR)  Carnets.15  The  remaining  conventions  have  different  levels  of 
accession. To support the development of efficient transit systems, CSATTF has identified the need 
for (i) modernizing existing bilateral agreements, (ii) developing a transit strategy based on bilateral 
or  multilateral  agreements,  (iii)  developing  a  single  transit  document  based  on  a  single 
administrative document, (iv) developing TIR in the region, and (v) examining the potential for other 
transit systems. The development of a CSATTF transit strategy and action plan covering these 
areas is needed to make further progress in improving transit systems.

laundering are major challenges to the subregion. CSATTF encourages its member countries to

12.  Consultations, Knowledge Sharing, and Capacity Development. ADB has encouraged 
among CSATTF member countries active consultations, including meetings not only among high-
level government officials (ministerial level) but also among technocrats and professionals, and 
development partners. Meetings also serve as forums for sharing knowledge related to trade and 
transport facilitation. So far, two ministerial conferences and two technical working group meetings 
have been held.  
 
13.  Trade and Investment. The last 2 years have shown a growing need to review the current 
trade and investment environment that influence the demand for trade and transport along the 
corridors. An appropriate strategy and action plan needs to be developed. 
  
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
14.  The intended impact of the TA is expanded economic activities in the subregion. The 
envisaged outcome of the TA is institutionalization among CSATTF member countries of systematic 
approaches to improve transport and trade facilitation in the subregion. Outputs that will support the 
impact and outcome are strategy and action programs on (i) transport infrastructure and services 
(including  brief  prefeasibility  studies  on  priority  projects  or  programs,  incorporating  public  and 
private–partnership  [PPP]  opportunities);  (ii)  customs  and  transit  systems;  (iii)  anti-trafficking, 
money laundering, and HIV/AIDS; and (iv) trade and investment. The strategy and action programs 
include (i) assessment of economic activities and their implications for transport and trade in the 
region; (ii) a diagnostic review of (a) transport infrastructure and services along the two CSATTF 
corridors, (b) customs and transit systems (including border and customs-related facilities), (c) drug 
and human trafficking, money laundering, and HIV/AIDS, and (d) trade and investment; and (iii) 
capacity development programs on trade and transport facilitation in support of the strategy and 
action plans.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
15.  The approach and methodology will be drawn from, and build on, the operational experience 
of ADB’s regional cooperation programs and development partners, as well as lessons learned in 
the field. The TA will provide CSATTF members (including both public and private sectors) and 
ADB’s development partners with joint consultation opportunities to address transport and trade 
facilitation issues in the subregion through working group meetings and seminars. It will also 
provide opportunities for sharing knowledge of international best practices in trade and transport 
facilitation, and capacity development.  
 
16.  Consultants will conduct site visits and interviews, and gather data from both the public and 
private sectors. The consultants also will (i) assess existing and future economic activities that 
generate and influence demand for trade and transport in the subregion, and (ii) conduct diagnostic 
reviews of (a) transport infrastructure and services along the two CSATTF corridors (including PPP 
opportunities), (b) customs and transit systems (including border and customs-related facilities), (c) 
drug and human trafficking, money laundering, and HIV/AIDS; and (d) trade and investment. They

will also collaborate with personnel involved in ongoing programs of all development partners. On 
the basis of these activities, the consultants will prepare strategy and action plan reports on (i) 
transport  infrastructure  and  services;  (ii)  customs  and  transit  systems;  (iii)  drug  and  human 
trafficking, money laundering, and HIV/AIDS; and (iv) trade and investment. The main report will 
summarize the findings of these reports and include an assessment of economic activities and their 
impact on trade and traffic, and capacity development programs. Draft reports will be reviewed by 
ADB, working group members, and CSATTF member countries. The final strategy and action plans 
will  be  presented  at  the  Third  Ministerial  Conference  for  its  endorsement  of  implementation. 
International experts will also provide advisory services during the TA implementation. Apart from 
the sector coverage envisaged, the TA will review additional cooperation opportunities that will also 
enhance regional cooperation in the subregion. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
17.  The TA is estimated to cost $950,000 and will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s TA 
funding program. Details of the cost estimates and the financing plan are in Appendix 2.   
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements   
18.  ADB will be the Executing Agency for the TA and will work with CSATTF member countries 
and ADB’s development partners.17 Under the TA, five international sector experts will be engaged 
for a total of 17 person-months. In addition, a senior TA advisor (domestic consultant) and a senior 
project analyst (domestic consultant) will be engaged for 24 person-months, respectively, to support 
TA  implementation.  The  consultants  will  be  stationed  in  the  Secretariat  at  the  Operations 
Coordination Division, SARD. Their outline terms of reference are in Appendix 3. ADB will select 
the consultants, on an individual basis, in accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants 
and other arrangements satisfactory to ADB for selecting domestic consultants.18 
 
19.  The TA will be implemented over 24 months starting in January 2006 and will be completed 
in December 2007.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
20.  The  President,  acting  under  the  authority  delegated  by  the  Board,  has  approved  the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $950,000 on a grant basis for 
Subregional Economic Cooperation in South and Central Asia (Phase II), and hereby reports this 
action to the Board.  
                                                 
17 SARD’s Transport and Communications Division (SATC) and Governance, Finance, and Trade Division (SAGF) will 
implement their respective sector components of the TA, together with Regional and Sustainable Development 
Department (RSDD) as appropriate. Staff at the ADB resident missions in Afghanistan and Pakistan as well as those in 
Tajikistan and Uzbekistan will also assist the secretariat. Close operational coordination between SARD and ECRD will 
continue to be ensured during TA implementation through the interdepartmental coordination mechanism developed 
during the last 2 years. 
18 Assistance to each participating developing member country (DMC) will not begin until ADB receives no objection from 
the government of the participating DMC.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
 
A.  Senior Technical Assistance (TA) Advisor (domestic) (24 person-months) 
 
1.  One senior TA advisor based at the CSATTF (CSATTF) secretariat at Asian Development 
Bank (ADB) headquarters will be engaged. The responsibilities will include the following tasks: 
 
(i)  Advise on the overall TA program and related operational issues. 
(ii)  Assist ADB staff in preparing for and implementing conferences and meetings for the 
TA, including steering committee meetings and sector working group meetings. 
(iii)  Prepare TA-related documents and papers as required. 
(iv)  Review, comment on, and edit TA-related documents prepared by the sector experts 
and others as required. 
(v)  Manage the information database on the participating countries. 
(vi)  Ensure the smooth flow of documents and communications between the consultants 
and  the  respective  ADB  departments,  and  between  ADB  and  the  participating 
governments.  
(vii)  Assist sector experts, together with a senior project analyst, in developing databases 
on transport infrastructure, and border and customs-related facilities.  
(viii)  Together with the senior project analyst, develop the CSATTF website.  
(ix)  Participate in ADB missions, as required by ADB staff. 
 
B.  Sector Experts (international)  
 
2.  A total of 17 person-months of consulting inputs will be required. A team of five internationally 
and individually recruited consultants will be engaged to prepare detailed strategy and action plans on 
(ii) transport infrastructure and services (multimodal); (iii) customs and transit systems (including 
border and customs-related facilities); (iv) anti-trafficking, money laundering, and HIV/AIDS; and (v) 
trade and investment. Their expertise will be in (i) economics; (ii) transport infrastructure and services 
(multimodal); (iii) customs and transit systems (including border and customs-related facilities); (iv) 
anti-trafficking, money laundering, and HIV/AIDS; and (v) trade and investment. The international 
consultants will ensure adequate understanding of the subregion both technically and politically, 
including constraints and opportunities. They  will collaborate with personnel involved in ongoing 
programs of all development partners.  
 
3.  In general, the consultants will undertake the following tasks: 
 
(i)  Identify and review relevant available ADB operational reports and TA studies including 
the Transport and Trade Facilitation Program of the Central Asia Regional Economic 
Cooperation (CAREC).

1.  Team Leader (Economist) (4 person-months) 
 
5.  An internationally recruited consultant will be engaged for 4 person-months, to serve as team 
leader  and  to  coordinate  the  activities  of  all  consultants  (including  support  to  the  Ministerial 
Conference and relevant working group meetings). The team leader will do the following: 
 
(i)  Coordinate and monitor the activities of all other consultants who will report to ADB 
through the team leader on a regular basis. 
(ii)  Facilitate the implementation of the study and ensure regular communication between 
the consultants, ADB, and the governments of CSATTF member countries. 
(iii)  Ensure  that  the  reports  submitted  by  all  consultants  are  of  high  quality  and  are 
consistent in style and presentation.  
(iv)  Prepare the main report that will consolidate and synthesize the main findings of the 
sector  studies,  assessment  of  the  economic  activities  and  their  implications  for 
transport and trade in the region over the medium- and long-term horizon, and capacity 
development programs on trade and transport facilitation in support of the strategy and 
action plans.   
 
6.  The main report will include the following: 
 
(i)  Review of overall economic activities along the CSATTF corridors and identification of 
comparative advantages. 
(ii)  Review of existing cross-border activities and regional plans. 
(iii)  Assessment of future economic development along the corridors and their implications 
for transport and trade in the region over the medium- and long-term horizon. 
(iv)  Identification  of  major  socioeconomic  constraints  to  closer  regional  economic 
cooperation, including those that affect the development of the private sector. 
(v)  Identification of potential areas and sectors for regional economic cooperation, which 
are not originally included in the TA. 
(vi)  Identification of the major public sector policies and programs that are required for the 
development of the corridors. 
(vii)  Identification of projects that are likely to benefit from closer regional cooperation. 
(viii)  Assessment of the overall financing requirements for the development of the corridors, 
including specific priority project and program profiles.  
(ix)  Development of systematic coordination mechanisms for (a) transport infrastructure 
and services; (b) customs and transit systems; (c) drug and human trafficking, money 
laundering, and HIV/AIDS; and (d) trade and investment, including all contact details of 
personnel from both public and private sectors, and major development partners.  
(x)  Identification of institutions at various levels that are needed to promote cooperation 
along the corridors. 
 
7.  In addition, the team leader will address any issue that is not covered by the sector specialists 
and  is likely to be of importance to the corridors.

D.  Reporting Requirements 
 
13.  Consultants are expected to regularly inform ADB of TA activities, consultants’ field schedules 
and trips, discussions with CSATTF member countries and stakeholders, and results of diagnostic 
reviews.  
 
14.  International sector specialists will submit draft interim reports to ADB and the team leader 1 
month from the start of services. They will also submit draft final reports to ADB and the team leader 
for  review  and  comment  2  weeks  before  the  completion  of  services.  After  the  comments  are 
incorporated, the specialists will submit the final reports to the team leader and ADB at the completion 
of services. The team leader will prepare a main report that will consolidate and synthesize the main 
findings of the sector studies, assessment of economic activities and their implications for transport 
and trade in the region over the medium- and long-term horizon, capacity development programs on 
trade  and  transport  facilitation  in  support  of  the  strategy  and  action  plans,  overall  financing 
requirements for developing the corridors including specific priority project or program profiles (brief 
prefeasibility studies), and systematic CSATTF coordination mechanisms. The reports will be used as 
bases for discussion at relevant working group meetings and will be further refined by incorporating 
suggestions made. The final strategy and action plans will be presented at the third Ministerial 
Conference for its endorsement of implementation. 
 
15.  In  addition  to  reports,  consultants  are  expected  to  produce  studies  related  to  trade  and 
transport facilitation in the subregion for ministerial conferences and working group meetings.
